channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [DERBY-5456] Problems running SecureServerTest and replication tests on Open JDK 7 for Mac OS X
item.environment: mac os x 10.6.8, OpenJDK Runtime Environment (build 1.7.0-b210-20110929)
item.summary: Problems running SecureServerTest and replication tests on Open JDK 7 for Mac OS X

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
This may be a machine configuration issue. Some questions:
Do you have an entry for richard-hillegas-computer.local (or maybe without .local will suffice) in /etc/hosts, or can it otherwise be resolved?
Is there more than one NIC on the computer?
Are you running both IPv4 and IPv6?

Another issue would be to figure out how these tests differ from the other network tests spawning a network server when it comes to obtaining/resolving the host name.

Thanks for those questions, Kristian. Here are some answers:

1) Do you have an entry for richard-hillegas-computer.local (or maybe without .local will suffice) in /etc/hosts, or can it otherwise be resolved?

Nope. /etc/hosts has entries for localhost and broadcasthost but not for richard-hillegas-computer.local. That latter, unknown name is what is printed out when I type the hostname command.

2) Is there more than one NIC on the computer?

Not that I can see.

3) Are you running both IPv4 and IPv6?

Yes.

Thanks.

I have found a bug in the open jdk 7 preview for mac os x which causes server startup to cough up the following warning:

Warning: UnknkownHostException: richard-hillegas-computer.local: richard-hillegas-computer.local: nodename nor servname provided, or not known.

This bug is tracked by http://java.net/jira/browse/MACOSX_PORT-564

In addition, it seems to me that server startup could be made more robust. Right now, it gives up collecting local addresses if it encounters a problem. If the server didn't give up, then it would eventually collect the local address it needs. I will attach a patch to make server startup more robust.

Attaching derby-5456-01-aa-moreRobustStartup.diff. This patch makes the server continue collecting local addresses if one of its attempts fails. The failures are not supposed to be fatal, they just result in the server printing a warning to derby.log. With this patch, SecureServerTest runs cleanly on the open jdk 7 preview for mac os x. I will run full regression tests now.

Touches the following file:

M java/drda/org/apache/derby/impl/drda/NetworkServerControlImpl.java

Tests passed cleanly for me on Java 6 except for the error below. This error does not seem to me to be related to this change. Committed at subversion revision 1183463.

Time: 5,975.721
There was 1 failure:

FAILURES!!!
Tests run: 11647, Failures: 1, Errors: 0
I suppose it would have been more robust to use InetAddress.getLoopbackAddress(), since it doesn't depend on name resolution. Unfortunately, that method is only available on Java 7.
All tests passed cleanly for my on the open jdk 7 preview for mac os x. That includes SecureServerTest and the replication tests.
Ported 1183463 from trunk to 10.8 branch at subversion revision 1185277.

I have verified that these errors do not occur any more using the latest build (220) of the OpenJDK 7 preview for Mac OS X. I verified this by running the full regression suite on build 220 using Derby 10.8.2.2. I did see 7 unrelated errors (the trigger-related errors in the upgrade tests, which have been fixed on the trunk).
